children.text: This is Lever Weekly, a recap of our work from the past week. If you only read one email from us all week, this should be it.

Below you will find a breakdown of our reporting, podcasts, videos, and live events ‚Äî a feature now open to all subscribers. Following that, we are providing paid subscribers with an original column, written by a member of
The Lever
, connecting the dots on our coverage to deliver important takeaways.
In this week‚Äôs column, exclusively for paid subscribers,
Managing Editor Joel Warner
explores the big-money interests jockeying to control cannabis legalization efforts in the wake of President Joe Biden‚Äôs recently announced
marijuana reform proposal

children.html:
SPREAD THE WORD: Share this article on Twitter and forward this email to encourage others to subscribe to The Lever.

Rock The Boat.

Read a preview below and click here to upgrade for full access.

Rock The Boat.

children.text: Stuff
The Lever
Reported This Week:
Health Insurers Get Government Cash, Then Jack Up Prices
‚Äî

‚ÄúThe nation‚Äôs major health insurance companies are receiving most of their money from the government, they just jacked up prices by double digits, and nearly half of the country is now underinsured or uninsured.‚Äù
Capitalizing On The Refugee Crisis
‚Äî

‚Äú[Big] companies are bankrolling GOP politicians who are raising campaign money off of their public abuse of immigrants ‚Äî while mistreating their workers and expressly tying the worth of refugees to their labor productivity.‚Äù
GOP Govs Reject Cannabis Pardons After Getting Private Prison Cash
‚Äî

‚ÄúThose three governors have raked in more than $263,000 from donors linked to the private prison industry, which profits off tough-on-crime policies and incarceration. In all, the private prison industry has funneled more than $1 million into state elections in the last 4 years, mostly to Republicans.‚Äù
A $21 Million Anti-Abortion Ad Blitz In Michigan
‚Äî
‚ÄúAnti-abortion forces have recently flooded the airwaves with more than $13 million worth of negative ads ‚Äî outspending pro-choice groups in the state by nearly two to one.‚Äù
Intel‚Äôs Multi-Billion Bait And Switch
‚Äî

‚ÄúJust a couple of months after Intel‚Äôs multi-million dollar lobbying effort succeeded in winning microchip companies billions of dollars in no-strings-attached corporate subsidies, Intel is reportedly planning to lay off thousands of workers.‚Äù
Will Louisiana Finally Get Its First Black Senator?
‚Äî

‚ÄúWhen every policy decision is made in this state about resources that are allocated to solve problems, Black people are disadvantaged in that conversation. And taxation without representation is about as un-American as you can be, right?‚Äù
YOU LOVE TO SEE IT: Gig Workers Get A Leg Up
‚Äî

‚ÄúAlso, an anti-abortion case with national ramifications was stopped in its tracks, unionized nurses in the Midwest are holding hospitals accountable, wind farms are proving to be a great return on investment, and Delaware is breaking cycles of debt with a bold new policy.‚Äù
üéßLEVER TIME: Biden's Marijuana Plan: The Good, The Bad, And The Corporate Interests
‚Äî
‚ÄúJoel and Shaleen break down every aspect of Biden‚Äôs plan, as well as the corporate interests hoping to turn a profit from marijuana legalization.‚Äù
üéßTHE AUDIT: We‚Äôre Auditing George W. Bush‚Äôs MasterClass
‚Äî
‚ÄúDave, Josh, and Kate pick apart Bush‚Äôs whitewashing of his own legacy, offer a retrospective on his charmed life in Texas, and mull the disastrous consequences of his presidency.‚Äù
üéßLEVER LIVE: Billionaires‚Äô Doomsday Prep (w/ Douglas Rushkoff)
‚Äî

‚ÄúDavid Sirota is joined by media theorist Douglas Rushkoff to discuss the very real machinations of the ultra-wealthy as they prepare for a ‚Äòworld-ending‚Äô event. Unfortunately for us ‚Äî they‚Äôre only planning on saving themselves.‚Äù
üéß LEVER TIME PREMIUM: How To "Ruggedize" Your Life (w/ Alex Steffen)
‚Äî

‚ÄúDavid Sirota chats with acclaimed climate futurist Alex Steffen about the practicalities of building sustainable infrastructure, and how to ‚Äúruggedize‚Äù your life in the face of climate change.‚Äù
Weed The People

At the start of 2014, as a Colorado-based freelance writer, I began reporting on the launch of the world‚Äôs first legalized cannabis industry. For the next four years, I covered the legalization of marijuana for publications large and small. I attended a flashy cannabis convention in Las Vegas, shadowed the country‚Äôs top marijuana prohibitionist in Washington, D.C., explored the country‚Äôs only government-run pot shop in Washington state, and embedded with old-school marijuana farmers in the California hills.

At the end of my time on the beat, I came away with an unexpected realization: Legal cannabis, despite decades of strict prohibition and societal taboos, was shaping up to become just like any other business.
That development, as illustrated by
The Lever
‚Äôs coverage this week, is both a relief ‚Äî and a cause for concern.
The upside to cannabis becoming boring? None of the apocalyptic things that legalization opponents predicted came to pass. Criminal activity
didn‚Äôt skyrocket
, teens didn‚Äôt
didn‚Äôt all become stoners
, and the highways
didn‚Äôt become death traps
. Most importantly, the
racist harms
of the country‚Äôs long, fruitless drug war began, little by little, to recede.
Such positive developments are likely why
two in three Americans
now support legalizing marijuana, And they are likely why two weeks ago President Joe Biden, a major architect of the War on Drugs, conceded it was time for a change,
declaring
: ‚ÄúToo many lives have been upended because of our failed approach to marijuana. It‚Äôs time that we right these wrongs.‚Äù
Biden
announced

he was pardoning all federal offenses of simple marijuana possession, called on state governors to follow his lead, and directed his administration to expeditiously review rescheduling cannabis so it will no longer be deemed a highly dangerous substance with no medical use.
While the moves were incremental and limited by caveats, they are still historic concessions by a former drug warrior ‚Äî and set the stage for more sweeping reforms.

But there is also a serious downside to cannabis turning into a typical industry. Just like every other U.S. business, that means marijuana is at risk of being shaped by political machinations and dominated by corporate greed.
The Lever
illustrated the former phenomenon earlier this week, when we revealed how Republican governors were rejecting Biden‚Äôs call to pardon people with low-level marijuana convictions after receiving
major donations

from the private prison industry. It‚Äôs bad enough that people are languishing behind bars because of cannabis. It‚Äôs even worse if they are forced to remain there not because of some twisted conception of justice or community safety, but simply because private prison contractors want to keep making money.
Prison companies aren‚Äôt the only for-profit businesses working to shape cannabis reform efforts. Opioid manufacturers
have spent big money
defeating legalization measures, and they are likely to spend far more as it becomes increasingly clear that regulated cannabis is majorly
cutting into the market
for prescription painkillers.
But corporate interests aren‚Äôt just working to curtail legalization. They‚Äôre also angling to take over the marijuana market, once it goes fully legal.
Prominent drug policy activist Shaleen Title made this point
on
Lever Time

this week. As she told me during a segment on Biden‚Äôs cannabis reform efforts, ‚ÄúIf cannabis is in fact descheduled, that‚Äôs when you will see the big corporate interests like Amazon, Big Tobacco, Big Alcohol, and Big Pharma [come in], all of whom are waiting in the wings. And so that is not a process that we want to rush in any form.‚Äù
The groundwork for that corporate takeover is already being laid. Andrew Freedman, Colorado‚Äôs first marijuana czar, now runs
a policy group
dedicated to ‚Äúestablishing a responsible and equitable federal regulatory framework for cannabis in the United States‚Äù ‚Äî which
is backed by funding from
the tobacco firm Altria and the beer corporations Molson Coors and Constellation Brands.
And does anyone really think Amazon is simply being altruistic in actively
pushing to legalize marijuana

Maybe you think it doesn‚Äôt matter who is growing, processing, and distributing cannabis, as long as it is free of federal and state prohibition. But consider this: Do we really want marijuana controlled by the very companies that have made a science of maximizing addiction for profit, and that are crushing small business and labor all over the country and beyond?

children.text: Here‚Äôs the good news: Unlike many industries in this country, the takeover hasn‚Äôt succeeded yet. Federal and most state marijuana regulations have yet to be written, a nationwide market is still at least several years away. So it is still possible to hold accountable those who will be rewriting the rules on cannabis, to make sure that righting the country‚Äôs cannabis wrongs, as Biden put it, includes efforts that protect small farmers, medical marijuana patients, home-grow aficionados, mom-and-pop operators, rank-and-file workers, and the Black and Brown communities that suffered the worst from the country‚Äôs failed drug war.

As Title noted on our podcast, ‚ÄúAs citizens, we don‚Äôt necessarily control how industries are going to roll out. But when it comes to this particular industry, those officials that want the credit of having legalized cannabis, they‚Äôre listening to people, and they‚Äôre especially listening to young people and consumers.‚Äù

Now, in other words, is the time to speak up. While Biden signaled he is taking steps to end the country‚Äôs ‚Äúfailed approach‚Äù to marijuana, it‚Äôll be up to the broader public to properly launch a new one.
